text: <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding inhibitors of NF-kappaB

<extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> ABIN-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> ABIN-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> TNIP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TNIP-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> TNIP-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) were identified as ubiquitously expressed <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interacting proteins and were shown to inhibit NF-kappaB activation by <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and several other inflammatory stimuli upon overexpression .
Because ABINs contain a specific ubiquitin - binding motif , they have been proposed to target <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to polyubiquitinated substrates [ 43 , 44 ] .

Similar to <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> ABIN-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is NF-kappaB dependent , implicating a potential role for the <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / ABIN complex in the negative feedback regulation of NF-kappaB activation ( reviewed in [ 54 ] ) .

Unexpectedly , both <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient and <extra_id_0> ABIN-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice exhibit only slightly increased or normal NF-kappaB responses , respectively , possibly reflecting redundant NF-kappaB inhibitory activities of multiple ABINs [ 55 , 56 ] .

Functional <extra_id_0> ABIN-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is expressed in humans , but mice only express a <extra_id_0> truncated and inactive form <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> lacking the crucial ubiquitin - binding domain [ 57 ] .

As for <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also strongly inhibits <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis [ 58 ] , and <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficient mice die embryonically due to <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent foetal liver apoptosis [ 56 ] .

Using oligonucleotide microarray analysis , <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was identified among <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced genes in human synoviocytes , and high levels of <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA were detected in RA tissue biopsies , indicating a potential role for <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , together with <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , in the negative feedback regulation of NF-kappaB signalling and the pathogenesis of RA [ 59 ] .

In a recent study , inhibition of TLR responses by immunoreceptor tyrosine - based activation motif ( ITAM ) - coupled receptors was shown to depend on the expression of the NF-kappaB inhibitory proteins <extra_id_0> ABIN-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Moreover , this protective effect of the ITAM was strongly suppressed in inflammatory arthritis synovial macrophages [ 60 ] .
Interestingly , <extra_id_0> ABIN-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> polymorphisms have been associated with psoriasis and systemic lupus erythematosus in humans [ 61 , 62 ] .

A high degree of overlap between systemic lupus erythematosus and RA susceptibility loci might be expected as the two diseases show some clinical overlap in joint involvement , autoantibody production , systemic features and response to treatments such as B-cell depletion ( rituximab ) .
It will therefore be interesting to investigate whether SNPs that have been reported to be associated with systemic lupus erythematosus are also associated with RA .
